qa.answer: Reflection of light is the bouncing back of light rays from a surface.
The laws of reflection are: (1) The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection. (2) The incident ray, reflected ray and the normal lie in the same plane.
A plane mirror is a mirror with a flat reflecting surface.
A concave mirror is a spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is curved inward.
A convex mirror is a spherical mirror whose reflecting surface is curved outward.
The principal focus is the point on the principal axis where rays parallel to the axis converge or appear to diverge after reflection.
The focal length is the distance between the pole and the principal focus of a mirror.
Magnification is the ratio of the height of the image to the height of the object.
Refraction of light is the bending of light when it passes from one medium to another.
Refractive index is the ratio of the speed of light in vacuum to the speed of light in a given medium.
The laws of refraction are: (1) The incident ray, refracted ray and the normal lie in the same plane. (2) The ratio of sine of angle of incidence to sine of angle of refraction is constant.
The human eye is a natural optical instrument which enables us to see objects.
Myopia is a defect of vision in which distant objects appear blurred.
Hypermetropia is a defect of vision in which nearby objects appear blurred.
Presbyopia is a defect of vision caused due to weakening of eye muscles with age.
Cataract is a condition in which the eye lens becomes cloudy, leading to loss of vision.
Dispersion of light is the splitting of white light into its constituent colours.
A rainbow is formed due to dispersion, refraction and total internal reflection of sunlight by water droplets.
